docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers have found that cleansing the body of a special category of cells could postpone many of the diseases that come with aging.

headline.seo: Senescent Cells Are Linked to Diseases of Aging, Study Finds
headline.main: Purging Cells in Mice Is Found to Combat Aging Ills
headline.print_headline: Prospect of Delaying Aging Ills Is Raised in Cell Study of Mice

docs.abstract: Researchers at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn, have found that cleansing the body of a special category of cells known as senescent cells could postpone many of the diseases that come with aging; team of researchers genetically engineered mice in which all the senescent cells can be purged by administering a drug that causes the cells to self-destruct; the results of the study are published in the journal Nature.
docs.snippet: Researchers have found that cleansing the body of a special category of cells could postpone many of the diseases that come with aging.

headline.main: Is China Facing a Health Care Crisis?

docs.abstract: Despite the government's effort to stimulate consumer spending, ordinary Chinese feel pressure to save money for medical expenses.
docs.snippet: Despite the government's effort to stimulate consumer spending, ordinary Chinese feel pressure to save money for medical expenses.

docs.lead_paragraph: A researcher asserts that antibiotics are permanently altering microbial flora of the human body, with unforeseen consequences.

headline.seo: Scientist Examines Possible Link Between Antibiotics and Obesity
headline.main: In Some Cases, Even Bad Bacteria May Be Good
headline.print_headline: In Some Cases, Even Bad Bacteria May Be Good

docs.abstract: Commentary published in journal Nature by Dr Martin Blaser asserts that antibiotics are permanently altering microbial flora of the human body, phenomenon that may be causing widespread health consequences; research by Blaser and others has led to foundation of Human Microbiome Project, which seeks to sequence genes of the diverse bacteria that populate the human body.
docs.snippet: A researcher asserts that antibiotics are permanently altering microbial flora of the human body, with unforeseen consequences.

docs.lead_paragraph: Six of 32 young male workers who went to a hospital with breathing problems died, and 16 others had disabling lung damage from breathing the fine sand, the study found.

headline.seo: Silicosis From Work on Blue Jeans Killed Workers, Study Says
headline.main: Turkey: Sandblasting Jeans for ‘Distressed’ Look Proved Harmful for Textile Workers
headline.print_headline: Turkey: Sandblasting Jeans for ‘Distressed’ Look Proved Harmful to Textile Workers

docs.abstract: Study published in journal Chest finds sandblasting new blue jeans to make them look 'distressed' caused number of young Turkish textile workers to die of lung deterioration before practice was outlawed.
docs.snippet: Six of 32 young male workers who went to a hospital with breathing problems died, and 16 others had disabling lung damage from breathing the fine sand, the study found.

docs.lead_paragraph: A study found insufficient evidence that dust and pollution in Iraq and Afghanistan could cause long-term health problems in returning troops.

headline.main: Study Finds Scant Data on Illnesses of Troops
headline.print_headline: Study Finds Scant Data On Illnesses Of Troops

docs.abstract: Federal study finds insufficient evidence that dust and pollution in war zones in Iraq and Afghanistan could cause long-term health problems in returning troops.
docs.snippet: A study found insufficient evidence that dust and pollution in Iraq and Afghanistan could cause long-term health problems in returning troops.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers report that a combination of fatty acids expands the heart cells of a well-fed snake, a finding that holds promise for treating human heart disease and other ailments.

headline.seo: Python Digestion Study Holds Promise for Human Heart Health
headline.main: Snakes’ Feat May Inspire Heart Drugs
headline.print_headline: Snakes’ Feat May Inspire Heart Drugs

docs.abstract: Study published in journal Science finds that a combination of fatty acids allows heart cells of a well-fed python to expand while snake digests its prey; study, conducted by scientists at the University of Colorado, holds promise for treating human heart disease and other ailments.
docs.snippet: Researchers report that a combination of fatty acids expands the heart cells of a well-fed snake, a finding that holds promise for treating human heart disease and other ailments.

byline.contributor: Maria Elkin contributed reporting from Washington.
